summary: This is a letter from the FBI to USCIS, dated June 18, 2024, supporting a T visa application for a female victim of sex trafficking who provided substantial assistance in the federal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. The letter details her cooperation from 2019 through 2021, her temporary departures from the U.S. to maintain lawful status, and the credible death threats she faced.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as a subject of the federal investigation for which the victim provided assistance.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named as a subject of the federal investigation for which the victim provided assistance.

persons.name: Assistant Special Agent in Charge
persons.context: The signatory of the FBI letter supporting the victim's T visa application.

connections.description: Both are named as subjects of the same federal investigation into sex trafficking.

events.title: Victim begins cooperation
events.description: The victim and her counsel began working with the federal investigation regarding Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: First departure from U.S.
events.description: The victim departed the United States to renew her E-2 visa, with notice to the FBI, to maintain lawful status for cooperation.

events.title: Application for Continued Presence
events.description: The victim traveled to FBI offices in Manhattan, was fingerprinted and photographed, and completed an application for Continued Presence as a trafficking victim assisting law enforcement.

events.title: Second departure from U.S.
events.description: The victim briefly left and returned to the U.S. on the same day to obtain a new admission stamp and extend her lawful status, with prior notice to the FBI.

events.title: Third departure from U.S.
events.description: The victim briefly left the United States to extend her lawful status further in order to continue cooperating with law enforcement.

locations: USCIS 38 River Road Essex Junction, Vermont 05479
keyFacts: A female victim of sex trafficking provided substantial assistance to the federal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell from 2019 through at least 2021.
The victim faced credible death threats as a result of being a victim of sex trafficking, which were investigated by the FBI.
The victim made three brief departures from the U.S. (Jan 2020, Aug 2020, Feb 2021) solely to maintain lawful immigration status so she could continue cooperating.
The U.S. Attorney's Office and FBI assisted her in applying for 'Continued Presence' status as a trafficking victim assisting law enforcement in July 2020.
The FBI is writing to USCIS to support the victim's application for a T visa, confirming her continuous physical presence and assistance.
